Midterm 2

This page will only include solutions to Problems 1 and 2, which were the ones I graded. The professor will provide solutions for Problems 3 and 4 elsewhere.

The solutions I write down here would receive full points from me. They aren't the only solutions that can receive full points, of course.

Problem 2

  1. State the Weierstrass MMM-test.
  2. Let f(x)=∑k=1∞fk(x)f\p{x} = \sum_{k=1}^\infty f_k\p{x}f(x)=∑k=1∞​fk​(x) where fk(x)=sin⁡(kx)k3f_k\p{x} = \frac{\sin\p{kx}}{k^3}fk​(x)=k3sin(kx)​.   1. Let (fn)n=1∞\p{f_n}_{n=1}^\infty(fn​)n=1∞​ be a sequence of bounded, real-valued functions on a metric space (X,dX)\p{X, d_X}(X,dX​). If

    converges, then ∑n=1∞fn\sum_{n=1}^\infty f_n∑n=1∞​fn​ converges uniformly to some function fff.

  2. We will use Theorem 3.7.1 to the sequence of partial sums Fn≔∑k=1nfkF_n \coloneqq \sum_{k=1}^n f_kFn​:=∑k=1n​fk​. To this end, we only need to check three things:

    • FnF_nFn​ is differentiable with continuous derivative.

    • FnF_nFn​ converges uniformly.

    • FnF_nFn​ converges at at least one x∈[−π,π]x \in \br{-\pi, \pi}x∈[−π,π].

    Since sin⁡(x)\sin\p{x}sin(x) is smooth, it is differentiable with continuous derivative. Thus, FnF_nFn​ is differentiable and Fn′F_n'Fn′​ is a sum of continuous functions, hence continuous itself. For the second condition, we use the MMM-test. Notice that

    ∣fk′(x)∣=∣cos⁡(kx)k2∣≤1k2.\abs{f_k'\p{x}} = \abs{\frac{\cos\p{kx}}{k^2}} \leq \frac{1}{k^2}.∣fk′​(x)∣=∣∣​k2cos(kx)​∣∣​≤k21​.

    Thus, ∥fk′∥∞≤1k2\norm{f_k'}_\infty \leq \frac{1}{k^2}∥fk′​∥∞​≤k21​, and ∑k=1∞1k2\sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{1}{k^2}∑k=1∞​k21​ converges by the ppp-test with p=2>1p = 2 > 1p=2>1, so by comparison, ∑k=1∞∥fk′∥∞\sum_{k=1}^\infty \lVert f_k' \rVert_\infty∑k=1∞​∥fk′​∥∞​ also converges. By the MMM-test, this implies that ∑k=1∞fk′\sum_{k=1}^\infty f_k'∑k=1∞​fk′​ converges uniformly. Lastly, like the hint suggests, ∑k=1∞fk(0)\sum_{k=1}^\infty f_k\p{0}∑k=1∞​fk​(0) converges (to 000). We may apply Theorem 3.7.1, which then implies that that fff is differentiable on [−π,π]\br{-\pi, \pi}[−π,π] with
